data.title: ‘WTF’ stands for something spicy at this incoming burger joint
data.meta_description: Kalamazoo artist plans to create world’s largest burger ever made to celebrate opening of new restaurant.
data.text:
PORTAGE, MI — A new burger joint coming to Portage is turning heads with its name — but that won’t be the only way it gets peoples’ attention.

What the Flavor Burger, or “WTF Burger” for short, is expected to open this fall at 2046 W. Centre Ave. in West Centre Plaza.

Don’t expect the restaurant to open quietly. Business owner Artist SinGh, of Kalamazoo, expects to enter the Guinness Book of World Records (again) by creating the world’s largest burger at the restaurant’s grand opening.

According to the Guinness Book of World Records, the current record was achieved in Germany in 2017 when six people created a burger weighing in at 2,566 pounds and nine ounces.

SinGh plans to surpass that with the first official WTF burger.

“It’s going to be a fun restaurant,” he said. “The response we’ve had just from ... our signs has been really humongous.”

As humongous as the record-setting burger he plans to make? Only time will tell.

While his grand opening stunt may seem ambitious, SinGh is no stranger to ambitious feats — or the Guinness Book of World Records.

He previously held the Guinness record for the world’s longest painting, for a 2.15-mile-long piece dubbed “The Transcendental” that took 38 days to complete and was entered into — and got him kicked out of — the 2013 Grand Rapids Art Prize.

Related: Guinness World Record awarded to 2-mile long painting booted out of ArtPrize 2013

He’s also been recognized for creating the world’s largest oil painting, largest easel and longest drawing. Then there is his feat of hanging upside down from a crane 70 feet off the ground and creating a painting while suspended in the air.

When it comes to his new restaurant, the India native hopes to win fans over with a different type of art. Cooking.

“The whole idea is to bring in flavor,” he said. “In America, we are more about salt and pepper. And that’s not how it is in India. My background is all Indian cuisine, which (uses) a lot of spices.

“So, I figured we could do something different, and at the same time, give people what they want.”

While he isn’t ready to share what the menu will look like entirely, there will be a signature burger called “The Ultimate WTF,” mixing true Indian flavor into an American classic.

In addition, WTF will serve build-your-own burgers and several kinds of fries, with at least one including multiple Indian spices.

Raised mostly in Dubai, SinGh came to the U.S. after high school to go to college. After earning a bachelor’s in business at Emporia State University in Kansas, he moved to Kalamazoo to be closer to his brother. He later earned a master’s degree from Spring Arbor University and also took master’s courses in business at Western Michigan University.

For the past decade-plus, he has operated his own gallery on South Burdick Street, which he’ll continue.

After opening his first WTF Burger in Portage this fall, SinGh plans to open two more in Grand Rapids, he said.

The Portage store, being built at a former Sheldon Cleaners on the corner of Oakland Drive and West Centre Avenue, was selected based on location.

With upward of 85,000 people living and working within a 5-mile radius, SinGh expects to stay busy with carryout and delivery orders. There will also be substantial seating for those who wish to eat inside.

WTF Burger does not plan to serve alcohol, just pop. It will also offer “quality food at an affordable price,” he said.

Social media pages and the website are in the process of being built.
